questions.text: A 39-year-old woman comes to the office with her husband because of a 2-month history of coarse, dark hair on her upper lip. Her husband reports that her voice has become deeper than usual. Menses previously occurred at 28-day intervals until 6 months ago when her menses stopped. Menarche occurred at age 13. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 57 kg (125 lb); BMI is 21 kg/m2. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows thick, dark hair along the upper lip and jawline and balding of the frontal scalp. There are no cutaneous lesions and a comparison of the patient's current appearance with previous photographs shows no evidence of hyperpigmentation. Neurological and abdominal examinations show no abnormalities. On pelvic examination, the clitoris appears enlarged; bimanual palpation discloses no masses. Serum testosterone and dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (DHEA-S) concentrations are significantly elevated. Serum 17-hydroxyprogesterone concentration is within the reference range. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

An androgen-secreting adrenocortical tumor (e.g., adrenocortical carcinoma) is the most likely cause of this patient's hyperandrogenism. DHEA-S is an androgen precursor that is produced by sulfation of DHEA in the adrenal cortex; elevated DHEA-S levels help to differentiate between adrenal and ovarian tumors in patients with hyperandrogenism. This patient's rapidly developing virilization also points toward androgen-producing tumors, because other disorders that manifest with hyperandrogenism, such as polycystic ovarian syndrome, present more insidiously.

While this patient probably has a pure androgen-producing adrenocortical tumor, most adrenocortical tumors also secrete corticosteroids and cause hypercortisolism (i.e., Cushing syndrome).

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with acromegaly, which is typically caused by a somatroph pituitary adenoma, can develop a deepening of the voice (due to vocal cord thickening and paranasal sinus enlargement) and secondary amenorrhea (due to hypogonadotropic hypogonadism). However, virilization with elevations in testosterone and DHEA-S would not occur in acromegaly. Moreover, other features of acromegaly (e.g., headache, macroglossia, organomegaly, coarsening of facial features) and pituitary macroadenomas (e.g., headache, visual disturbance) are not seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

Androgen-secreting ovarian tumors (e.g., Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors) can manifest with rapidly progressive features of hyperandrogenism. However, such tumors result in increased DHEA, but not in increased DHEA-S. Moreover, the absence of a palpable adnexal mass on bimanual pelvic examination further makes an ovarian tumor less likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Nonclassic congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), which is typically caused by a mild deficiency of 21β-hydroxylase, can manifest during adulthood with hirsutism, secondary amenorrhea, and increased DHEA-S levels. However, serum 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels are typically elevated in CAH, which is not the case here. Moreover, the symptoms of nonclassic CAH progress insidiously; the rapid onset and progression of virilization over 2 months suggest a different diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Cushing disease, an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma, can manifest with features of hyperandrogenism (e.g., hirsutism, menstrual irregularities) due to ACTH-mediated stimulation of androgen secretion from the adrenal glands, and patients with aggressive Cushing disease can have rapidly progressive symptoms. However, other features of secondary hypercortisolism (e.g., hyperpigmentation, central obesity, easy bruising, proximal muscle weakness) and pituitary enlargement (e.g., headache, visual disturbance) are not seen here.

F) INCORRECT:

Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) can cause mild features of hyperandrogenism (e.g., hirsutism, androgenic alopecia) and secondary amenorrhea with increased DHEA and testosterone levels (due to the conversion of DHEA to testosterone in the ovary). Elevated DHEA-S levels are seen in 20–30% of women with PCOS; functional adrenal hyperandrogenism is thought to be the cause. However, severe virilization with clitoromegaly and voice deepening is uncommon in PCOS. Moreover, the symptoms of PCOS typically begin during adolescence or early adulthood and progress insidiously; the rapid onset and progression of virilization over 2 months suggest a different diagnosis.
questions.hint: This patient's virilization (i.e., voice deepening, hirsutism, androgenic alopecia, clitoromegaly) and menstrual irregularities indicate hyperandrogenism. Her elevated DHEA-S levels help to identify the source of excess androgens.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old woman comes to the physician because of excessive hair growth. She has noticed increasing numbers of dark hairs on her upper lip and on her abdomen over the past 8 years. Menarche was at the age of 13 years. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last 5–6 days with moderate flow. She is sexually active with one male partner. Her only medication is a combination oral contraceptive. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 88 kg (193 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows coarse dark hair on the upper lip and periumbilical and periareolar skin. Her external genitalia appear normal. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Midcycle serum studies show:


Fasting glucose
95 mg/dL


Dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate
3.1 μg/mL (N = 0.5–5.4)


Luteinizing hormone
95 mIU/mL


Follicle-stimulating hormone
75 mIU/mL


17α-Hydroxyprogesterone
190 ng/dL (N = 20–300)


Testosterone
1.1 nmol/L (N < 3.5)


Dihydrotestosterone
435 pg/mL (N < 300)


A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptom?

choices.text: Androgen-producing tumor of the adrenal glands
Tumor of granulosa-theca cells of the ovary

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Increased 5-alpha reductase activity in hair follicles, which results in elevated dihydrotestosterone (DHT) levels, is the most likely explanation for the abnormal hair growth in this patient. DHT is a potent form of testosterone that causes hair follicles to transform into terminal hair, especially in androgen-sensitive areas of the body such as the upper lip, chin, and back. Hirsutism affects 5–10% of female patients and is usually idiopathic. It is associated with hyperandrogenism of ovarian or adrenal origin in 10% of cases.

B) INCORRECT:

An androgen-producing tumor of the adrenal glands would manifest with signs of virilization such as acne, alopecia, clitoromegaly, and deepening of the voice, none of which are present in this patient. In addition, laboratory studies would show elevated levels of testosterone and DHEA-S, which are also not seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

While exogenous androgen intake (anabolic steroid use) can lead to hirsutism, it is unlikely to be the cause in this patient, as her laboratory results show normal levels of androgens, LH, and FSH. Anabolic steroid use would be associated with decreased LH and FSH levels due to negative feedback from excess androgens.

D) INCORRECT:

21-hydroxylase deficiency, which typically affects adolescents, is characterized by hirsutism, acne, infertility, and/or irregular menstrual cycles, along with other features of virilization. Although this patient has evidence of hirsutism, she has none of the other features associated with CAH. Additionally, laboratory studies would show increased levels of 17-hydroxyprogesterone and DHEA-S.

E) INCORRECT:

Peripheral insulin resistance and the resulting hyperinsulinemia are thought to be part of the pathophysiology of PCOS. While hirsutism and obesity can occur in PCOS, the lack of other symptoms (e.g., menstrual irregularities, infertility, and acne vulgaris) makes this diagnosis less likely. In addition, laboratory studies would show elevated levels of glucose, LH (LH:FSH ratio > 2:1), testosterone, and DHEA-S, which are not seen here.

F) INCORRECT:

Granulosa-theca cell ovarian tumors are estrogen-producing ovarian tumors that most commonly affect postmenopausal women. These tumors typically manifest with menstrual irregularities and features of excess estrogen (e.g., breast tenderness, endometrial hyperplasia, or carcinoma), neither of which is seen in this patient. Laboratory evaluation would also reveal decreased levels of LH and FSH due to negative feedback caused by an excess of estrogen.
questions.hint: This woman presents with slow progression of hirsutism with normal ovulation and menstruation, normal gonadotropins, and normal testosterone and DHEA-S, which suggests idiopathic hirsutism.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man with hypertension and congestive heart failure is brought to the emergency department because of a 9-day history of worsening shortness of breath and swelling of his legs. His respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 160/98 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on 5 L O2 via nasal cannula shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Examination shows 2+ pretibial edema bilaterally. Crackles are heard at both lung bases. The patient's symptoms are due in part to an increase in the rate of bradykinin breakdown. The substance responsible for bradykinin breakdown is primarily produced in which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

ACE is produced by cells of the pulmonary endothelium. Circulating bradykinin is therefore primarily metabolized in the pulmonary vasculature.
Image Description:

Renin is produced in response to changes in the glomerular filtration rate and solute content of the blood within the renal corpuscle. Renin catalyzes the conversion of angiotensinogen (produced by the liver) to angiotensin I, which is then converted to angiotensin II by angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE; produced by the lungs). Angiotensin II acts to increase blood pressure by causing vasoconstriction, sodium retention, and ADH production.

The specific targets of the different RAAS inhibitors are highlighted in red.

B) INCORRECT:

ACE is not made in the liver. Angiotensinogen, however, is produced in the liver before being converted to angiotensin I by renin in the kidneys.

C) INCORRECT:

ACE is not made by the cardiac atria. Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP), however, is produced by atrial myocytes, which then acts on the kidneys.

D) INCORRECT:

ACE is not made in the zona glomerulosa. Aldosterone, however, is produced in the zona glomerulosa in response to angiotensin II, a substance converted from angiotensin I by ACE.

E) INCORRECT:

ACE is not made by juxtaglomerular cells. Renin, however, is produced by juxtaglomerular cells and converts angiotensinogen to angiotensin I.
questions.hint: Bradykinin is degraded by angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE), a component of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS).

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. His blood pressure was 146/91 mm Hg at his appointment 1 month ago; subsequent home blood pressure measurements have ranged from 135/83 mm Hg to 156/96 mm Hg. His blood pressure today is 141/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Pharmacotherapy with lisinopril is initiated. Administration of this drug is most likely to result in decreased activity of which of the following sections of a normal adrenal gland?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This is the fibrous adrenal capsule, which keeps the organ mechanically stable. Angiotensin II does not regulate the activity of the capsule.

B) CORRECT:

The zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex is the outermost layer of adrenal parenchyma and lies directly beneath the adrenal capsule (A). The cells of the zona glomerulosa are stimulated by angiotensin II to produce mineralocorticoids, most importantly aldosterone. Inhibition of ACE by lisinopril leads to decreased availability of angiotensin II, in turn resulting in decreased activity of the zona glomerulosa. The response of the zona glomerulosa to angiotensin II is attenuated by low serum potassium or high serum sodium levels.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of the adrenal cortex (Ladewig trichrome stain; 100x magnification)

The adrenal gland consists of three layers.
– Zona glomerulosa: located directly beneath the capsule; consists of ovoid cells, which are arranged in clusters and produce mineralocorticoids
– Zona fasciculata: consists of cells that are arranged in bundles and produce glucocorticoids
– Zona reticularis: consists of cells arranged in cords, giving it a net-like structure; produces androgens

The adrenal medulla consists of cells that produce catecholamines.

C) INCORRECT:

The zona fasciculata is the middle portion of adrenal cortical parenchyma. The cells of the zona fasciculata are stimulated by adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) to produce glucocorticoids, including cortisol. Inhibition of ACE and subsequent changes in angiotensin II levels are not involved in ACTH secretion. The activity of the zona fasciculata is therefore not affected by lisinopril therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

The zona reticularis is the innermost portion of the adrenal cortical parenchyma. The cells of the zona reticularis are stimulated by adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) to produce androgens, including androstenedione and dehydroepiandrosterone. Inhibition of ACE and subsequent changes in angiotensin II levels are not involved in ACTH secretion. The activity of the zona reticularis is therefore not affected by lisinopril therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

The adrenal medulla is the innermost part of the adrenal gland and contains chromaffin cells that secrete norepinephrine and epinephrine when triggered by the cholinergic sympathetic preganglionic nerve fibers lying in close proximity. The inhibition of ACE and the subsequent changes in angiotensin II levels do not directly affect acetylcholine stimulation of the adrenal medulla.
Image Description:

Innervation (left) and synaptic signaling of chromaffin cells (right) in the adrenal medulla.

1 and 2: Preganglionic sympathetic fibers from the thoracic spine directly innervate the chromaffin cells, which are neuroendocrine cells similar in structure to sympathetic neurons.
3. An action potential opens a voltage-gated calcium channel.
4. The increased calcium ion concentration within the synaptic cell triggers the release of the neurotransmitter acetylcholine (ACh) from vesicles into the synaptic cleft.
5. The nicotinic ACh receptors on the chromaffin cells are ligand-gated ion channels. The influx of sodium ions triggers depolarization of the cell, which leads to the opening of voltage-gated calcium channels.
6. The increased calcium ion concentration within the chromaffin cell triggers the secretion of norepinephrine and epinephrine from the secretory granules into the bloodstream. Approx. 80% of chromaffin cells produce epinephrine, while only 20% produce norepinephrine.
7. The predominant serum catecholamine is norepinephrine (80%). This increase in serum norepinephrine occurs because norepinephrine is also secreted as a neurotransmitter by the postganglionic fibers from the sympathetic trunk, while epinephrine is produced almost exclusively by the adrenal gland.
questions.hint: Lisinopril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor that blocks the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II. Angiotensin II is the primary regulator of aldosterone production in the adrenal cortex.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man is brought to the emergency room after a blunt-force injury to the abdomen. His pulse is 130/min and blood pressure is 70/40 mm Hg. Abdominal ultrasound shows a large amount of blood in the hepatorenal recess and the pelvis. Which of the following responses by the kidney is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

When the RAAS is activated, increased aldosterone will act at the collecting tubules of the nephron to increase proton secretion. This effect would increase, rather than decrease, proton excretion.

B) INCORRECT:

When the RAAS is activated, increased aldosterone will act at the collecting tubules of the nephron to increase potassium secretion. This effect would increase, rather than decrease, potassium excretion.

C) CORRECT:

Increased aldosterone increases the reabsorption of sodium and the secretion of potassium and protons in renal collecting tubules. In addition, angiotensin II increases the glomerular filtration rate and stimulates sodium reabsorption in the proximal tubule. As sodium is reabsorbed, water follows from the glomerular filtrate into the renal interstitium. This fluid shift into the peritubular capillaries eventually leads to increased intravascular fluid and increased blood pressure.

D) INCORRECT:

Urea reabsorption occurs in the proximal tubule and the collecting duct, and is expected to be increased in hypovolemia. Volume loss causes increased levels of ADH, which induces the expression of urea transporters in the medullary collecting ducts, leading to an increase in urea reabsorption. Reabsorption of urea in the collecting ducts is essential to maintain the inner medullary osmotic gradient that allows for maximal retention of filtered water. Urea is also reabsorbed in the proximal tubule via diffusion through the solvent drag of other electrolytes. This mechanism is also increased in hypovolemic states because of increased urine concentration and interstitial electrolyte concentration.

E) INCORRECT:

Under physiological conditions, creatinine is removed from the blood by glomerular filtration and tubular secretion at a relatively constant rate. Although creatinine can be absorbed in the gastrointestinal tract (dietary supplements or meat), there is little to no renal tubular reabsorption of creatinine. Because of decreased renal perfusion, this patient is at risk of decreased glomerular filtration and thus increased serum creatinine. However, any rise in serum creatinine is a result of decreased clearance (decreased GFR) rather than as a result of increased renal absorption.
questions.hint: In renal hypoperfusion, the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) is activated, meaning the kidneys release renin, which leads to activation and release of angiotensin II and aldosterone.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of unintentional weight gain of 5.5 kg (12.2 lb) and irregular menstrual cycles over the past 2 months. She does not take any medications. Her blood pressure is 155/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows central obesity, hyperpigmentation of the palmar creases, and violaceous scarring of the abdomen. Early morning serum cortisol levels are elevated and serum adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is within the reference range after a low-dose dexamethasone suppression test. A high-dose dexamethasone suppression test shows suppression of ACTH. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Benign adenoma of the adrenal medulla
Nodular hypertrophy of the zona reticularis
Bilateral hyperplasia of the zona fasciculata
Unilateral carcinoma of the adrenal cortex

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pituitary gland atrophy is observed in Sheehan syndrome, which presents with hypopituitarism. The earliest presenting symptom is failure to lactate after delivery due to impaired prolactin secretion, which can also be followed by sequential development of secondary hypogonadism, hypothyroidism, and adrenal insufficiency. Even though this patient has menstrual irregularity, she does not have clinical features of hypothyroidism or adrenal insufficiency, nor risk factors for Sheehan syndrome (e.g., recent pregnancy), and her serum ACTH level does not align with hypopituitarism.

B) INCORRECT:

Benign adenoma of the adrenal medulla affects chromaffin cells, which are regulated by preganglionic sympathetic fibers. Pheochromocytoma is a chromaffin cell tumor that is mostly benign and affects the adrenal medulla in 90% of cases. Its clinical features include episodic hypertension, paroxysmal palpitation, headache, and pallor due to sympathetic hyperstimulation as a result of excess catecholamine secretion. This patient does not have any of these features.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with Cushing disease will have diffuse and bilateral zona reticularis hyperplasia (not hypertrophy) due to excessive ACTH-dependent adrenocortical stimulation.

D) CORRECT:

This patient with Cushing disease most likely has bilateral hyperplasia of the zona fasciculata due to excessive ACTH-dependent adrenocortical stimulation. In addition, excessive pituitary or ectopic ACTH production leads to development of hyperpigmentation in areas not normally exposed to the sun as seen in this patient's palmar crease. This results from increased collateral melanocyte stimulating hormone production, which is cleaved from the same precursor protein (proopiomelanocortin) as ACTH.

E) INCORRECT:

Excessive cortisol secreted by an adrenal cortex tumor can cause many clinical features of Cushing syndrome, such as this patient's weight gain with central obesity, abdominal striae, hypertension, and irregular menses. However, unlike ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome, adrenocortical cancer does not induce skin hyperpigmentation as there is no increased collateral melanocyte stimulating hormone secretion. Additionally, elevated cortisol would cause decreased ACTH levels (unlike in this patient), since cortisol suppresses the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis through a negative feedback loop.
questions.hint: This patient has signs of Cushing syndrome: weight gain with central obesity, abdominal striae, hypertension, hyperpigmentation, and irregular menses. A positive low-dose dexamethasone suppression test indicates hypercortisolism. A serum ACTH within the reference range in this context is considered abnormal, as ACTH secretion should physiologically be suppressed by elevated serum cortisol levels. Suppression of ACTH with high-dose dexamethasone confirms increased ACTH production from the pituitary gland (Cushing disease).

questions.text: A 20-year-old man is brought to the emergency room for evaluation of a back injury sustained while at work. A CT scan of the lumbar spine shows an incidental 2-cm mass adjacent to the inferior vena cava. Histologic examination of a biopsy specimen of the mass shows clusters of chromaffin cells. This mass is most likely to secrete which of the following substances?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In the peripheral nervous system, catecholamines such as norepinephrine are synthesized in chromaffin cells, mainly in the adrenal medulla. Chromaffin cells are neuroendocrine cells that originate from the neural crest and migrate to the paraganglia and adrenal medulla during embryonic development. Tumors from these cells are called pheochromocytomas, which are mostly found in the adrenal gland but can also be extra-adrenal, as seen in this patient. Besides norepinephrine, most pheochromocytomas also secrete other catecholamines such as epinephrine and dopamine, causing hypertension. Some tumors also secrete EPO, which can lead to polycythemia.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of normal adrenal tissue (H&E stain; low magnification)

Layers from top to bottom:

– Fibrous adrenal capsule (dashed line)
– Glomerular zone (Gz): composed of cells that produce mineralocorticoids
– Fascicular zone (Fz, white overlay): large pale cells produce glucocorticoids
– Reticular zone (Rz, green overlay): eosinophilic cells produce sex hormones
– Medulla (M): composed of adrenaline and noradrenaline-producing cells

No abnormalities are present.

B) INCORRECT:

Cortisol is secreted by cells of the zona fasciculata of the adrenal cortex. The adrenal cortex is derived from lateral plate mesoderm and does not contain chromaffin cells, which are derivatives of the neural crest.

C) INCORRECT:

In females, most of the estrogen is produced by the granulosa cells of the ovary; in both sexes, it is produced to some extent in the adrenal cortex and adipose tissue. Both the adrenal cortex and the adipose tissue are mainly derived from mesoderm and do not contain chromaffin cells, which are derivatives of the neural crest.

D) INCORRECT:

Dehydroepiandrosterone is secreted by the zona reticularis of the adrenal cortex. The adrenal cortex is derived from lateral plate mesoderm and does not contain chromaffin cells, which are derivatives of the neural crest.

E) INCORRECT:

Aldosterone is secreted by the zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex. The adrenal cortex is derived from lateral plate mesoderm and does not contain chromaffin cells, which are derivatives of the neural crest.
questions.hint: Chromaffin cell tumors are neuroendocrine tumors that usually originate from a tissue that develops from the neural crest.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the regulation of adrenal hormone synthesis in rats. The investigator takes serum concentrations of different hormones before and after intravenous administration of metyrapone, which inhibits adrenal 11β-hydroxylase. The serum concentration of which of the following hormones is most likely to be decreased after administration of this agent?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serum concentration of adrenocorticotropic hormone will be increased in this experiment, since metyrapone reduces cortisol production by inhibiting 11β-hydroxylase. Consequently, the negative feedback loop of glucocorticoids, which inhibit the secretion of CRH and ACTH, will be impaired.
Image Description:

The hypothalamus releases gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH), and thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) into the portal vessels of the pituitary stalk, through which they reach the anterior pituitary gland. These hypothalamic hormones then directly influence the release of tropic hormones from the anterior pituitary gland into the peripheral bloodstream. GnRH stimulates the release of both luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), CRH stimulates adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), and TRH stimulates thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH).

LH and FSH act on the ovaries/testes to produce sex hormones (estrogen, progesterone, and testosterone); ACTH stimulates the adrenal gland to produce glucocorticoids (primarily cortisol); and TSH stimulates the thyroid gland to produce thyroid hormones (T3 and T4).

The hypothalamus also influences the release of nontropic hormones like prolactin and growth hormone (GH) from the anterior pituitary gland. Prolactin regulates lactation in the mammary glands; GH is stimulated by growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH) and in turn stimulates the production of insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) in the liver.

Hormone secretion is regulated by feedback loops, where the hormones produced by target organs can inhibit the release of their controlling hormones from the hypothalamus and pituitary.

B) INCORRECT:

Serum concentration of normetanephrine will most likely be increased in this experiment. Cortisol physiologically decreases the activity of catechol-O-methyl transferase (COMT), which breaks down catecholamines. If cortisol production is reduced, more norepinephrine is converted to normetanephrine by COMT.

C) CORRECT:

Epinephrine production is stimulated by cortisol as part of the fight-or-flight response. This cortisol effect is mediated by an increased expression of the enzyme that converts norepinephrine to epinephrine, phenylethanolamine-N-methyltransferase (PNMT). Consequently, serum concentration of epinephrine decreases if metyrapone is administered, since it reduces cortisol production and thereby decreases expression of PNMT. A decrease in this enzyme, in turn, results in reduced conversion of norepinephrine to epinephrine.
Image Description:

Overview of the biosynthesis and breakdown of the catecholamines dopamine, norepinephrine and epinephrine, starting with the amino acid phenylalanine and showing enzymes (blue text) and cofactors (blue highlighting).

The glucocorticoid cortisol induces expression of phenylethanolamine N-methyltransferase and thus the conversion of norepinephrine to epinephrine. The drug carbidopa (used, e.g., in Parkinson disease) inhibits DOPA decarboxylase and thus the peripheral conversion of L-DOPA to dopamine.

Congenital diseases may occur due to enzyme deficiencies, as shown here for phenylketonuria (1; defect in phenylalanine hydroxylase), albinism (2; defect in tyrosinase), and alkaptonuria (3; defect in homogentisate oxidase).

D) INCORRECT:

Serum concentration of norepinephrine will most likely be increased in this experiment. Conversion of dopamine to norepinephrine is catalyzed by dopamine beta-hydroxylase in a vitamin C-dependent reaction, which is not induced by cortisol. However, the subsequent reactions in which dopamine acts as a substrate would be impaired, since cortisol production is inhibited by metyrapone.

E) INCORRECT:

Serum concentration of dopamine will most likely be increased in this experiment. Conversion of DOPA to dopamine is catalyzed by DOPA decarboxylase in vitamin B6-dependent reactions, which are not induced by cortisol. However, the subsequent reactions in which dopamine acts as a substrate would be impaired, since cortisol production is inhibited by metyrapone.
questions.hint: Metyrapone blocks the conversion of 11-deoxycortisol to cortisol. Cortisol physiologically increases the expression of phenylethanolamine-N-methyltransferase (PNMT) in the adrenal gland.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old healthy woman has her plasma adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), aldosterone, corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH), and cortisol measured at 8 am (baseline). She then receives 1 mg of dexamethasone at 11 pm, and at 8 am the following morning, the same hormones are re-measured. Which of the following best reflects the expected change in hormone levels on the second day compared to the baseline?



ACTH
Aldosterone
CRH
Cortisol



A
Unchanged
unchanged
increased
increased


B
Increased
increased
unchanged
unchanged


C
Unchanged
increased
decreased
increased


D
Decreased
unchanged
decreased
decreased


E
Increased
decreased
increased
unchanged


F
Decreased
decreased
unchanged
decreased
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aldosterone levels will remain unchanged, but dexamethasone does not increase CRH or cortisol levels; it suppresses hypothalamic CRH and pituitary ACTH production, thereby lowering endogenous cortisol production.

B) INCORRECT:

Dexamethasone suppresses both CRH and ACTH production, so neither ACTH nor cortisol can remain unchanged or increase. Moreover, an increase in aldosterone levels is not expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Although CRH levels will decrease following dexamethasone administration, ACTH and cortisol levels will also decrease in parallel, and an increase in aldosterone levels is not expected.

D) CORRECT:

Dexamethasone provides supraphysiologic negative feedback to both the hypothalamus and pituitary, sharply reducing CRH production from the hypothalamus and ACTH production from the anterior pituitary. With diminished ACTH production, endogenous glucocorticoid production from the zona fasciculata of the adrenal cortex also decreases, so plasma cortisol falls by the next morning. In contrast, endogenous mineralocorticoid (aldosterone) secretion is governed chiefly by the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system and serum potassium, and a transient ACTH suppression produces no appreciable change.

In patients with Cushing syndrome (hypercortisolism), cortisol levels will remain elevated following a low-dose (1 mg) dexamethasone suppression test. Higher doses of dexamethasone can decrease cortisol levels in patients with hypercortisolism due to Cushing disease (ACTH production by a pituitary adenoma).

Key learning point: Negative feedback loops in the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis regulate endogenous glucocorticoid production.

E) INCORRECT:

A glucocorticoid challenge never provokes rises in CRH or ACTH; it uniformly suppresses them and thus lowers cortisol. Moreover, aldosterone would not decrease from this intervention.

F) INCORRECT:

While ACTH and cortisol levels do decrease following dexamethasone administration, CRH levels are expected to decrease similarly due to negative feedback. Moreover, aldosterone would not decrease following a glucocorticoid challenge.
questions.hint: Endogenous glucocorticoid (e.g., cortisol) production is regulated by the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis. Dexamethasone is a potent synthetic glucocorticoid, but dexamethasone is not converted to cortisol, and the cortisol assay does not detect dexamethasone itself.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man is admitted to the ICU for severe pneumonia requiring mechanical ventilation. Over the past 48 hours, he has had minimal oral intake. Despite fluid resuscitation, he continues to have tachycardia and mild hypotension. Morning blood glucose levels remain in the 8–10 mmol/L range, and serum free fatty acid levels are elevated.
Which of the following best explains these laboratory findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Adrenal insufficiency leads to decreased cortisol, reducing gluconeogenesis and lipolysis, resulting in lower free fatty acids and blood glucose. The elevated free fatty acids and hyperglycemia in this patient indicate a stress-induced hormonal surge, not cortisol deficiency.

B) INCORRECT:

Prolonged inactivity causes muscle wasting over weeks to months, primarily affecting skeletal muscle, not adipose tissue metabolism. It does not acutely increase free fatty acids.

C) INCORRECT:

Intravenous glucose typically raises blood glucose but also stimulates insulin release, which suppresses lipolysis and decreases free fatty acids. The elevated free fatty acids in this patient, despite hyperglycemia, suggest a stress-related metabolic response rather than nutrient overload.

D) CORRECT:

Critical illness triggers a stress response mediated by hormones such as cortisol, catecholamines, and glucagon. These hormones enhance gluconeogenesis in the liver, raising blood glucose levels, and promote lipolysis in adipose tissue, leading to elevated free fatty acids. This metabolic adaptation ensures energy availability for vital organs during physiological stress, even with reduced nutritional intake.

Key learning point: In critically ill patients, the metabolic response to stress includes increased insulin resistance, increased gluconeogenesis, and increased lipolysis to provide energy substrates for vital organs.
